From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Thanks everyone for the positive feedback. I'll attempt to respond to
all o=
f the questions/points in one email...


Stefano - good to hear your resear=
ch has broadly similar findings. Do
you have links to one or two specific e=
xamples?


Ken - SELUs. I didn't encounter them in my recent brief survey o=
f
possible candidates to look into, but that does look intriguing. I was
ac=
tually thinking of trying something similar to leaky ReLU but with a
curve =
instead of a hard threshold; the idea being that I think the
hard threshold=
 may not be conducive for control tasks where
intuitively I feel that a con=
tinuous relationship between inputs and
outputs will generally be superior.=
 E.g. I briefly applied ReLU to
single pole balancing and the solutions wer=
e all ones where the pole
wiggled back and forth, rather than just being al=
most dead vertical &
stationary.

So yes I'll definitely look into it. The =
use of exp() for negative
inputs may affect performance of course, but defi=
nitely worth
investigating.

Alex - Re. heterogenous activation functions (=
HA-NEAT). Yeh would be
interesting to see how your HA-NEAT implementation p=
erforms on the two
benchmark tasks I've been using. I see you ran to 3000 g=
enerations,
i.e. held the number of gens constant, whereas I'm holding cloc=
k time
constant. Probably to be a fair comparison on the underlying techniq=
ue
I'd have to hold gens or evaluation count constant (as per Jeff's
commen=
ts). Thanks for the paper, and good luck with the GECCO
presentation.


Pab=
lo - Re. the tiny slope on the leaky ReLU based functions. I did
use a tiny=
 gradient of just 0.001. Given how tiny this is it seems
likely to me that =
there would be no qualitative difference between
this and a non-leaky ReLU.=
 I'm happy to try it though just to be sure
(Jeff seconded that question).
=

I used leaky ReLU because I was keen for there to be at least some
kind of=
 gradient to follow, and at the time I though it would reduce
the chance of=
 random weight mutation drifting to very large values.
But of course follow=
ing a shallow fitness gradient could also lead to
very large weights - I on=
ly just realised that. It should prevent
random weight drift though, in pri=
nciple that shouldn't matter because
there's no gradient, but some future n=
etwork mutation could bring that
weight back into a part of the fitness lan=
dscape with a gradient, so
maybe my instinct on this is reasonable.

Re. th=
e 'Proportional' activation function, that's in an older code
base I think,=
 but yeh was just y=3Dx with the output y clipped to [0,1],
I guess you'd c=
all that non-leaky SReLU nowadays.


Jeff -

> Would you mind letting us kn=
ow how these figures look holding the number of
> evaluations constant?

Ye=
s I'll have a go. I agree that would be useful. I have my reasons
for choos=
ing clock time as I was focused on overall speed of finding
solutions, but =
I agree it's useful to understand the relative
performance of these functio=
ns independent of execution speed. In real
world practical applications the=
re's a balance to be had, but we need
the raw results/science to understand=
 that balance.


> we=E2=80=99d love to see these same results on more/hard=
er problems.

Sure. Do you have any in mind? I'm happy to discuss this furt=
her. It's
true that my tasks are sort of 'toy' tasks, but again this was a
=
conscious choice. These tasks are non-trivial, or certainly more
complex th=
an XOR (say), but don't require much CPU time to evaluate.
This results in =
NEAT being run to some quite high generation and
evaluation counts within e=
ach one minute run, so we get to see lots of
cumulative mutations, some lar=
ge networks forming, and a general
stress testing of the SharpNEAT code bas=
e.

By distributing out to more CPUs/nodes we can perhaps look into slower
=
to evaluate but more interesting tasks, but still keep total
experiment tim=
e reasonable.


>  I can volunteer the computing resources from U. Wyoming =
to give you the ability to
> conduct a larger study

Cool, thanks. In princ=
iple it should be possible to run the core
SharpNEAT algorithm on .NET Core=
 on unix/linux with minimal effort,
assuming it's a *nix cluster with x86/6=
4 CPUs(?). It's certainly worth
considering.


Thanks again,

Colin
